conclusion: Understanding the relationship between light source, objects, and shadows
A (shadow of the apple) is cast to the right of the apple
Size and position of shadow A determined by angle and distance of light source relative to apple
B (shadow of the paper) is cast to the right of the paper
Size and position of shadow B determined by angle and distance of light source relative to paper
C (shadow of the glass) is cast to the left of the glass
Size and position of shadow C determined by angle and distance of light source relative to glass
D (shadow of the chicken leg) is cast to the right of the chicken leg
Size and position of shadow D determined by angle and distance of light source relative to chicken leg
Moving the light source upward changes the angle at which light hits objects
Shadows will generally become shorter and move closer to objects
A (apple shadow) will move closer to the apple and become shorter
B (paper shadow) will move closer to the paper and become shorter
C (glass shadow) will move closer to the glass and become shorter
D (chicken leg shadow) will move closer to the chicken leg and become shorter
Final answer: Shadows A, B, C, and D will all become shorter and move closer to their respective objects
